trial_identification.studytitle: Corneal Collagen Cross-linking (CXL) as an adjunct in the treatment of Microbial Keratitis
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In patients with microbial keratitis, is conventional treatment plus corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL) more effective than conventional treatment alone in terms of time to healing, visual results, and secondary interventions required?

interventions.interventions: riboflavin 0.1% indextran solution is applied to the cornea every 2 minutes for 30 minutes, and then ultraviolet A light at 365nm and 3 watts/cm2 exposure is applied for a further 30 minutes
interventions.comparator: Conventional topical antibiotic therapy, commencing with broad spectrum antibiotics such as Ofloxacin 0.3%, one drop every hour for 24 hours and then modification of dosage according to clinical response.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Time to resolution of microbial keratitis - initial daily examination using slitlamp biomicroscopy to detect healing of epithelial defect and resolution of stromal infiltrate

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: presumed or confirmed microbial keratitis of moderate severity or worse
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Pregnancy impending or actual corneal perforation

trial_design.concealment: Trial participation offered to all eligible patients presenting to the RVEEH

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Microbial keratitis is a significant cause of ocular morbidity and visual loss, as well as a significant health cost to the community. Ultraviolet light is known to be microbicidal. We think it is likely that the proposed treatment will lead to quicker recovery from this serious eye infection and better visual outcomes.
